section_title: Variables and Data Types in Python
section_description: This section introduces the fundamental concepts of variables and data types in Python. You will learn how to store and manipulate different kinds of data using variables. Understanding these concepts is essential for writing effective Python programs.
learning_objectives: Declare and assign values to variables in Python.
Identify and use the four basic data types: int, float, str, and bool.
Check the data type of a variable using the type() function.
Convert between different data types using type casting.
Apply variables and data types to solve simple programming problems.

lessons.lesson_objective: Define and assign values to variables in Python.

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create three variables: name, age, and city. Assign your name (string), age (integer), and hometown (string) to them. Print each variable on a separate line.

lessons.lesson_objective: Identify and use int, float, str, and bool data types in Python.
key_topics: Using type() to check data types

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create one variable for each basic data type (int, float, str, bool). Assign appropriate values. Use the type() function to print the data type of each variable.

lessons.lesson_objective: Convert between data types using int(), float(), and str().

exercises.exercise_instructions: Ask the user to enter their age as a string. Convert it to an integer, add 10 to it, then convert the result back to a string. Print a message: 'In 10 years, you will be X years old.', replacing X with the result.

Create a variable celsius with a value of 25. Convert it to a string and print: 'The temperature is 25 degrees Celsius.' Then convert it to float and multiply by 9/5, then add 32 to get Fahrenheit. Print the result.

lessons.lesson_objective: Manipulate strings using concatenation and basic methods.

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create variables first_name and last_name. Concatenate them into a full name using an f-string. Print a greeting: 'Hello, [full name]!'
Create a string variable with your favorite word. Print its length and the first character using indexing (e.g., word[0]).
